item.name: Events
item.title: National Night Out
item.body:
Organize a neighborhood block party, barbecue, ice cream social or other outdoor event that brings neighbors together.

2018 National Night Out Public Party Locations (Map Version)

2018 National Night Out Public Party Locations (PDF Version)

Register by July 20, 2018 to receive give-aways for the kids, and a special gift for the host.

Sponsored by the National Association of Town Watch, NNO is America's night out and a time for neighbors to get together to build neighborhood spirit and unity. Research shows that when neighbors know each other, neighborhoods are safer.

Planning resources:

  • Block Party Guide
  • Sample Program Ideas
  • Getting to Know You Questions
  • Customizable Flyer English Spanish Chinese

item.body: From May to October, free walking tours every Wednesday and Saturday highlight Downtown Oakland's history and ongoing renaissance. Get a glimpse of today’s happening scene and landmarks from Oakland’s past on 8 different itineraries. View the itineraries and schedule.

item.body: The Edible Demonstration Gardens at Lake Merritt offer FREE workshops and volunteer days from April thru November. Merritt College Horticultural Department, volunteer participation days every Wednesday from 9:30-11am. Seasonal vegetables by seasoned gardeners!

item.name: Events
item.title: Toddler's Garden Volunteer Days
item.body:
The Edible Demonstration Gardens at Lake Merritt offer FREE workshops and volunteer days from April thru November.

Toddler's Garden, with fun garden demos for toddlers aged 4 and under! All workshops begin at 10 am. Join us for more toddler-based garden workshops throughout the fall!

item.name: Events
item.title: Cambodian Women's Garden Group Volunteer Days
item.body: The Edible Demonstration Gardens at Lake Merritt offer FREE workshops and volunteer days from April thru November. Cambodian Women's Garden Group leads garden demonstrations every 2nd Friday from 1-3pm. Learn and experience new methods of gardening from experts!

item.name: Events
item.title: Oakland Creek to Bay Day
item.body:
Volunteers of all ages and abilities are invited to join Oakland Creek to Bay Day projects to clean and green Oakland’s creeks, shorelines, parks, and neighborhoods. Projects include trash removal, habitat restoration, tree planting, and beautification.

The 23rd annual Oakland Creek to Bay Day is part of California and International Coastal Cleanup Day, the largest volunteer day in California and the world! Be a part of it!

Visit www.oaklandcreektobayday.org to sign up as a site coordinator, register individuals or groups of volunteers, or find more information.

item.name: Events
item.title: Oakland Toy Drive Registration for Families #1
item.body:
Registration takes place at Oakland City Hall. Hearing Room 2. Please enter through the 14th Street side door. Signs will be posted.

On Saturday, November 3, 10 and 17th 12 pm – 4 pm the City of Oakland is holding registration for all eligible Oakland residents to receive toys for their children this holiday season.

The Toy Drive is partnering again with the Animal and Community Resource Network to provide bags of dog and cat food to those toy recipients with pets.

Applicants do not need to line up before 12 pm as this is not a first come first served program – everyone that comes will get served.

To qualify please bring:

  • Picture ID
  • Proof of Oakland residence (rent agreement, PG&E or phone bill)
  • Proof of Children’s ages (birth certificate, medical card or social security number) Ages 0-12 up to 4 children per family.
  • Proof of income (MediCal card, IRS statement or paycheck st

item.name: Events
item.title: East Oakland Neighborhoods Initiative Kick-Off Meeting
item.body:
Please join us at 10am!

During this kick-off meeting at Allen Temple Baptist Church, community partners will go over the structure and goals for the upcoming year of work, and share opportunities to get involved. East Oakland Neighborhoods Initiative partners will be seeking community feedback to guide our efforts. At this meeting, you can expect:

- FREE food and beverages

- Introduction from community partners and City of Oakland staff

- Breakout discussion sessions on urban greening, affordable housing, clean energy, transportation, disaster preparedness, and more

- Opportunity to speak with City of Oakland staff from the Planning, Transportation, Resilience, Sustainability, Business Development, and Public Works Departments

item.name: Events
item.title: Winter Shelter is Now Open

address.street2: The Society of Saint Vincent de Paul

item.body:
The City of Oakland opened its winter shelter at the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul, 675 23rdStreet, Oakland, CA 94612. The shelter operates 7-days a week until June 30, 2019.

The shelter provides beds for up to 65 homeless Oakland and Emeryville adult men and women (no minors) through December 1, 2018, and will then expand to a capacity of 100. The shelter beds can be secured through referral, reservation, and walk up-first come-first served basis. Shelter doors open to clients by 6 PM each evening and close by 8 AM every morning.

item.name: Events
item.title: Holiday Caroling on Lake Merritt
item.body: Holiday Caroling On Lake Merritt – From December 1 through December 23, on all Thursdays through Sundays the Lake Merritt Boating Center is offering on-the-water tours launching from 568 Bellevue Avenue inside Lakeside Park. Enjoy some time in the Holiday room with hot cider and cookies before beginning your voyage of singing around Lake Merritt. Experience a unique view of Oakland as your Water Sleigh glides past the 18th Street Fountain & Holiday Cove before returning to the Boating Center. Times vary. The admission fee is $8 per person or $120 for the whole boat. For more information and to view the flyer, please visit www.sailoakland.com. For more information, please contact Sarah Herbelin, Boating Supervisor, at sherbelin@oaklandca.gov.

item.name: Events
item.title: Oakland Toy Drive Distribution for Families
item.body:
Families who have signed up for toys in November can come to City Hall (during unique specified pick up times) between 10am-4pm on Saturday, December 15 to pick up their gifts!



During the holidays, the City of Oakland collects and distributes toys for Oakland children. Last year, we were able to provide toys to over 8,000 children from low-income families. This includes over 16,000 dolls, trucks, books, board games, sports equipment, and gift certificates. NOTE: TOY DRIVE WILL BE HELD EARLIER THIS YEAR ON SATURDAY, DECEMBER 15, 2018.



Registration takes place at Oakland City Hall. Hearing Room 2. Please enter through the 14th Street side door. Signs will be posted.

On Saturday, November 3, 10 and 17th 12 pm – 4 pm the City of Oakland is holding registration for all eligible Oakland residents to receive toys for their children this holiday season.


The Toy Drive is partnering again with the Animal and Community Resource Network to provide bags of dog and cat food to those toy recipients with pets.

Applicants do not need to line up before 12 pm as this is not a first come first served program – everyone that comes will get served.

To qualify please bring:

  • Picture ID
  • Proof of Oakland residence (rent agreement, PG&E or phone bill)
  • Proof of Children’s ages (birth certificate, medical card or social security number) Ages 0-12 up to 4 children per family.
  • Proof of income (MediCal card, IRS statement or paycheck stub)

item.name: Events
item.title: Studio One Winter Break Camp
item.body:
Week 1: December 26 - December 28

Week 2: January 2 - January 4

Resident Rate: $135
Non-Resident Rate: $162

Pre-Care ($7/day): 7:30am - 9am
After Care ($7/day): 5pm -6:30pm

When School is out, art is in! Keep your kids creative and engaged over

Thanksgiving and Winter Break with 4 fun classes a day.

Classes may include paper crafts, painting, drawing, textiles,

sculpture, movement, and more! Camp hours are

9am - 5pm. pre-care and after care available.

item.name: Events
item.title: MLK Day of Service
item.body:
Service for Peace has partnered with Oakland Public Works to lead this annually in Oakland since 2003, engaging thousands of volunteers in projects to clean and green Oakland. The Corporation for National and Community Service helps sponsor the event in Oakland, and throughout the nation, where hundreds of thousands of volunteers pitch in on similar community service projects.

“Everybody can be great, because everybody can serve.” – Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

item.title: Summer Camp Fair
item.body:
FREE Admission to the Bay Area Summer Camp Fair. Plan your summer in a day!
On March 10, 2019 (at The Lakeside Park Garden Center, 666 Bellevue Ave, Oakland CA. From 12 p.m. - 4 p.m.)

Come meet with the people that provide programming for youth in our community. Representatives from Non-Profits, for-Profit, Public, Day and Overnight Specialty Camps will be represented.

The FREE fair runs from 12 p.m. – 4 p.m.
There will be a wide variety of schools and camps for children, teens and families.

If you would like to be a vendor at this event please email studiooneartcenter@gmail.com with “Camp Fair” in the subject line

item.name: Events
item.title: Human Services Department Request for Qualifications For Professional Services - Notice of Qualifications Update (7/2/19)
item.body:
July 2, 2019 Update: Notifications of Qualification have been emailed for all Service Categories.

June 10, 2019 Update: Notifications of Qualification have been emailed for Service Categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 7. Proposals for Services Category 5 are still under review.

Thank you for your participation!

The City of Oakland is pleased to release a Request for Qualifications (RFQ) to provide professional services for the Human Services Department for services initiated during the July 2019 through June 2022 period. Services include (but are not limited to) research and evaluation, marketing and communication, strategic planning, training and capacity building for community providers, as well as capacity building for workforce providers and employer engagement.

See below for important dates and to download the RFQ materials.

  • RFQ Issue Date: March 15, 2019
  • Pre-Proposal Meeting: March 26, 2019
    3 - 4:30 p.m., City Hall, Hearing Room 1 - View the meeting participant list here
  • PROPOSALS DUE: Friday, April 19, 2019 at 2:00pm

HOW TO APPLY: Download and Review the Request for Qualifications

Applicants are required to register in iSupplier, see RFQ #138483

Questions:

Updated Q&A - posted Tuesday, April 16, 2019

Updated Q&A - posted Friday, April 5, 2019

Pre-Proposal Meeting Q&A - posted Monday, April 1, 2019

Please email questions regarding the RFQ to: OaklandHSD@oaklandca.gov

Q and A's will be posted on the Human Services Department website. The last date for questions is April 12, 2019 by 12:00 PM

item.name: Events
item.title: Walking Tour - Old Oakland
item.body:
Old Oakland Walking Tour

Walk through what was once the western terminus of the Transcontinental Railroad! Formerly Oakland’s bustling downtown district in the days of railroads and streetcars, this area’s grand, brick, commercial Victorian buildings, now restored, continue to thrive as offices, galleries and eateries. Visit the historic Washington Inn, G.B. Ratto & Co. International Grocers, Swans Marketplace and the “Friends of the Library” bookstore.

Meet at 10:00 a.m. in front of Ratto's International Market & Deli at 821 Washington Street.

Parking is available at the Oakland Convention Center, enter at 11th and Clay streets.
item.eventContact:
Phone Number: (510) 238-3234
Email Address: aallen@oaklandca.gov

Old Oakland Walking Tour

item.name: Events
item.title: Walking Tour - Preservation Park
item.body:
Preservation Park Walking Tour

A walking tour of a Victorian-era district adjacent to modern office towers. Sites include the historic First Unitarian Church, the Pardee Home Museum, and more than a dozen elegantly restored, 19th century houses -- now serving as nonprofit offices, meeting rooms, and conference spaces -- in a beautiful garden setting.

Meet at 10:00 a.m. in front of Preservation Park at 13th Street and Martin Luther King, Jr. Way.

Parking is available on Wednesdays at the City Center West Garage. Enter on Jefferson Street between 14th and 12th streets.
item.eventContact:
Phone Number: (510) 238-3234
Email Address: aallen@oaklandca.gov

Preservation Park Walking Tour

item.name: Events
item.title: Walking Tour - Waterfront
item.body:
Waterfront Walking Tour

The images of author Jack London will surround you as you tour the historic square and waterfront. Visit a turn-of-the-century wholesale produce district still in operation and see the USS Potomac, the restored yacht of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

Tour begins at 10:00 a.m. at the Jack London Square entry arch, foot of Broadway.

Parking is available at various garages and surface lots in the area.

item.body:
Uptown to the Lake Walking Tour

A walking tour of the Uptown District with an emphasis on Art Deco! Tour includes the Paramount Theatre, Historic Sweet’s Ballroom, the Fox Theater and the Kaiser Center roof garden with views of Lake Merritt.

item.name: Events
item.title: Walking Tour - City Center
item.body:
City Center Walking Tour

Turn-of-the-century landmarks alongside modern high-rises are the focus of this tour. Explore the upbeat style of the modern City Center Square and discover a thriving “there” there. Examine symbols of Oakland’s arrival as a modern 20th century metropolis: the Beaux Arts-style City hall and Rotunda Building, the Tribune Tower, and the Art Deco-style Financial Center building.

Tour begins at 10:00 a.m. in front of Oakland City Hall, One Frank H. Ogawa Plaza.

Parking is available at the Dalziel Garage. Enter on 16th Street between Clay Street and San Pablo Avenue.
item.eventContact:
Phone Number: (510) 238-3234

Email Address: aallen@oaklandca.gov

City Center Walking Tour

item.title: Walking Tour - Churches & Temples
item.body:

Visit historic places of worship and learn about their architecture and influence on the development of Oakland. Highlighted buildings include First Presbyterian, First Congregational, and First Christian churches as well as Temple Sinai.

Tour begins at 10:00 a.m. in front of the First Presbyterian Church, 2619 Broadway at 27th Street.

Parking is available at curbside meters.

item.name: Events
item.title: Public Hearing on Poverty in Alameda County
item.body:
Alameda County-Oakland Community Action Partnership is seeking comment from the community on its Community Action Plan (CAP) and input on the needs and gaps in services that exist for Alameda County's low-income residents.

View the Draft 2020-2021 CAP, and register to attend our Public Hearing on Monday, June 10, 2019 at 6pm at Oakland City Hall, Hearing Room 3. Not available to attend in person? email us your feedback at AC-OCAP@oaklandca.gov and have your voice be heard.

View the Public Hearing announcement in English, Spanish, or Chinese

The Community Action Plan (CAP) serves as a two year roadmap demonstrating how AC-OCAP plans to deliver services funded by the Community Services Block Grant (CSBG). The CAP identifies and assesses poverty related needs and resources in Alameda County and establishes a detailed plan, goals and priorities for delivering those services to individuals and families most affected by poverty.

item.name: Events
item.title: East Oakland Neighborhoods Initiative Final Convening
item.body:
Please join us for the final meeting of the East Oakland Neighborhoods Initiative! Throughout our year of community outreach, we have collected resident feedback on transportation, housing, economic development, parks, and other important issues in East Oakland. During our final convening, we will be sharing our findings, as well as recommended next steps. We want you to tell us what we missed, and what should be different!

Additional activities and offerings will include:

- Free food

- Raffle

- Kids games

- Music and entertainment

item.name: Events
item.title: Hidden Figures: The Power of Untapped Talent Pools - Postponed
item.body:
The workshop slated for Thursday, July 25 has been postponed. We'll reach out with the new date shortly. Sorry for the inconvenience.


Are you struggling to recruit employees to fill vacant positions? The reality is that there are available workers who are capable of filling your positions today.

Join us to learn how to connect with and make the most of our local untapped talent, build a talent pipeline for the future and access the resources available to attract, train and retain talent.


8:00 - 8:30 Registration & Coffee

8:30 - 9:15 Panel 1: Tapping into the Hidden Talent Pool
-Rehana Lerandeau, Fair Chance Programs Manager at Checkr
-Anthea Charles, Director at Marriott Foundation Bridges
-Tony Ozuna, Field HR Specialist at U.S. Coast Guard

9:30 - 10:15 Panel 2: How to Grow Your Own Talent
-Felicia Duncan, Program Manager for KP LAUNCH at Kaiser Permanente
-James Gardner, Ph.D., Executive Director, Association of Manufacturers Bay Area
-Pamm Shaw, Vice President, Early Childhood Impact, YMCA of the East Bay

10:30 - 11:15 Panel 3: Resources to Help You Access Hidden Talent
-Renée Pierce, Economic Development Analyst, CA Employment Training Panel
-Alfredo Mathew, Director of Strategic Partnerships, Earn & Learn East Bay
-Poonum Patel, Senior Business Development Specialist, California Governor’s Office of Business and Economic Development
-Sonja Brooks, Business Services/Community Relations Manager at the Oakland Private Industry Council

The Workshop will be delivered in English with simultaneous ASL, Cantonese, and Spanish interpretation. This meeting location is wheelchair accessible. To request any additional disability-related accommodations or Mandarin or other interpreter, please email twalker@oaklandca.gov or call (510) 238-3630 or 711 for relay service at least five working days before the meeting. Please refrain from wearing scented products to this meeting as a courtesy to attendees with chemical sensitivities.

Free parking is available in Lot C on Merritt’s campus.

Location:
Huey Newton & Bobby Seale Student Lounge
Merritt College, 12500 Campus Drive, Oakland

Hosted by the City of Oakland's Workforce Development Board.

item.name: Events
item.title: National Night Out 2019
item.body:
National Night Out is Tuesday, August 6, 2019 * 7pm-9pm

Organize a neighborhood block party, barbecue, ice cream social or other outdoor event that brings neighbors together.

City of Oakland staff, Oakland Police Department, Oakland Fire Department and elected officials will be out roaming the neighborhoods and will visit as many parties as possible.

Sponsored by the National Association of Town Watch, NNO is America's night out and a time for neighbors to get together to build neighborhood spirit and unity. Research shows that when neighbors know each other, neighborhoods are safer.

Register by July 26, 2019 to receive give-aways for the kids, and a special gift for the host.

We have a new City of Oakland portal called Oakapps that requires everyone to login with an account before filling out the form.

Register Now

item.title: Child Care Enrollment - Head Start for 3 to 5 year olds. 10 slots remaining.
item.body:
Our Center in Brookfield (near the Brookfield library) and our part-day program at Frank G. Mar (Chinatown) still have a few slots remaining. Call 510.238.3165 to enroll your child in this free, high-quality child development program. Give your child what they need to succeed in kindergarten and in life. You can enroll in person at 150 Frank Ogawa Plaza, 5th Floor, Suite 5352 or call us and we will let you know the nearest location to you.

More than Childcare

EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION: Children’s readiness for school and beyond is developed through learning designed for each child's individual needs. Staff and parents work together to develop a plan for each child. The program focuses on every child’s intellectual, social, emotional, and physical growth and development.

DISABILITIES SERVICES: 10% of slots are reserved for children with disabilities who have an Individualized Education Plan (IEP) or Individualized Family Service Plan (IFSP).

NUTRITION SERVICES: Every child is served a nutritious breakfast, lunch, and snacks daily. Special nutrition needs like allergies and special meals are offered.

FAMILY SERVICES: Families are given the opportunity to set goals and support to help meet their goals. Head Start also works with Community Partners to provide services and resources for families. Programs support and strengthen parent-child relationships and engage families around children’s learning and development. We link families to job training programs, education, and other family services.

HEALTH SERVICES: The program emphasizes the importance of preventive health care and early identiﬁcation and intervention of health problems. All children receive health and development screenings, vision screenings, dental care, and mental health support as part of the program.

The program is free. ENROLL NOW! 510.238.3165

item.title: The City of Oakland's Coat Drive
item.body:
The City of Oakland is collecting coats to help keep low-income families, seniors, and unsheltered residents warm this winter. Please deliver your gently worn coats to Oakland Marriott City Center at 1001 Broadway in Oakland on Monday, November 25th, 2019 between 1:00 pm and 4:00 pm. This coat drive is held in conjunction with the City of Oakland's 28th Annual Thanksgiving Dinner serving our seniors, low-income families, and unsheltered residents.

Click here for the Coat Drive flyer.

Click here for more information about the Thanksgiving Dinner.

item.name: Events
item.title: The City of Oakland’s 28th Annual Thanksgiving Dinner & Coat Give-Away
item.body:
The City of Oakland’s Human Services Department, Alameda County – Oakland Community Action Partnership, Communities United Committee, and the Emergency Food Providers Advisory Committee continue a much-loved Thanksgiving Dinner for the underserved of our community. This wonderful event will take place Tuesday, November 26, 2019 from 11:00AM – 2:00PM at the Downtown Oakland City Center Marriott, 1001 Broadway, Oakland.

The Thanksgiving Dinner, in its 28th year, is part of the City’s Hunger Program which was founded in 1985 during the mayoral administration of Lionel J. Wilson. With the support of donors and volunteers, the city serves 2000 low-income families, senior citizens, and persons experiencing homelessness in the City of Oakland with a hearty Thanksgiving meal in a communal festive atmosphere.

The City of Oakland also supports transportation to and from the event from our senior centers, low income housing programs, and shelters.

It is with ongoing community support and generous sponsorships that this event has reached its 28th year. Sponsors this year for which we are grateful:

  • Oakland Athletics
  • Golden State Warriors
  • Kaiser Permanente
  • City of Oakland Human Services Department
  • Alameda County-Oakland Community Action Partnership
  • Emergency Food Providers Advisory Committee

However, donations are still needed even now. Just $26 will provide a meal for one guest, $130 per family of five, and $260 per table of 10 guests. If interested in contributing, please make checks payable to the City of Oakland Hunger Program, 150 Frank H. Ogawa Plaza, Ste. 4340, Oakland, CA 94612. Donations are tax deductible. The tax identification number is 94-6000384.

For more information about this event, please contact 510.986.2721.

Find out more about donating your gently worn coats to the Coat Give-Away by clicking here.

item.name: Events
item.title: Howard Terminal Community Benefits Agreement (CBA) Orientation
item.body:
The Howard Terminal Community Benefits Agreement Participant Orientation officially launched the CBA process.

The orientation began with an equity presentation by the City of Oakland's Department of Race and Equity Director Darlene Flynn, to provide a foundation for the equity-centered development of the Howard Terminal CBA. Participants also broke into CBA topic groups and began to identify the benefits that may be considered in the CBA.

This orientation was mandatory for participants who wish to be involved in the development and adoption of the Howard Terminal Community Benefits Agreement, which will be included as a component of the overall project approval process. A make-up orientation will be offered on Monday, February 10, 2020 at 5:30pm at the CSUEB Oakland Center in the Rockridge Room.

item.body:
The workshop will include the following topics.

  • METRC Overivew;
  • METRC Onboarding process;
  • METRC Operational Best Practices;
  • METRC Tags, Inventory, Manifests and Transfers;

You will leave with a better understanding of what METRC is and some best practices for setting up SOP's and delegating roles and responsibilities within your organization. You will benefit from learning the implementation process from an experienced compliance officer.

RSVP for this workshop today, seats are limited.

item.name: Events
item.title: Howard Terminal CBA Topic Cohort Meeting
item.body:
The Howard Terminal Community Benefits Agreement (CBA) process launched on Saturday, January 11, 2020 with the CBA Orientation at Preservation Park, with over 150 community members, advocates, and other Oakland stakeholders in attendance. The orientation included a presentation by Darlene Flynn, Director of the Department of Race and Equity, and concluded with the attendees assembling into the CBA Topic Cohorts that they are interested in. Seven Topic Cohorts have been identified for the Howard Terminal CBA: Economic Development, Housing, Transportation, Community Health & Safety, Education, Environment, and Community History/Culture Keeping. The Topic Cohorts were identified based on engagement with community members, advocates, and other Oakland stakeholders in 2019. As the CBA process evolves, there may be additional topics introduced.

SAVE THE DATE

The first meeting of Topic Cohorts will be next Wednesday, January 22, 2020 from 6:30pm-8:30pm at the CSU East Bay Oakland Center.

All seven Topic Cohorts will gather at the January 22ndand will break into their cohorts after brief introductory remarks. If you are interested in being considered to represent your Topic Cohort on the Steering Committee, please plan to attend both Topic Cohort meetings. Additionally, if you were unable to attend the CBA Orientation but wish to remain involved, please plan to attend the Topic Cohort meetings listed below and additionally plan to attend a future make-up orientation for which more information will be forthcoming. Childcare will be provided at all meetings.

Veronica C. Cummings

item.name: Events
item.title: Staff Report for the Equity Grant Funds
item.body:
Our office will be presenting a resolution for the City Council’s consideration at the City Council’s Community and Economic Development (CED) Committee on Tuesday January 28th to receive and appropriate the Bureau of Cannabis Control’s (BCC) $1,657,201.65 Grant to support the City of Oakland’s Equity Program. In order for the City of Oakland to receive the BCC funding, our City Council must approve a resolution to accept the funding and authorize the City Administrator to enter into a grant agreement with the BCC.

For information on the proposed use of BCC grant funds, including staff’s recommendation to direct these funds towards grants to operators, commercial kitchens for equity manufacturers, support for events featuring equity businesses, workforce development programming, and a program analyst position to support grant and equity program administration, please review the staff report. Here is the agenda for the January 28th CED meeting the meeting is scheduled to begin at 12:30pm at City Hall in Hearing Room One, however, the cannabis grant item is the second to last item on the agenda.

item.name: Events
item.title: POSTPONED - Dedication Event - Gates for the Gardens at Lake Merritt
item.body:
POSTPONED - The dedication event has been postponed until later in the Spring.

The two hand-forged iron gates are in Lakeside Park, off Bellevue Avenue. The dedication event will be at the main gate adjacent to the Lakeside Park Garden Center. Light refreshments served in the Garden Center Vista Room following the dedication event.

This site-specific public art project was commissioned through the City’s 1.5 percent for art program, a 30-year-old program that ensures that public artwork is integrated into Oakland’s municipal capital projects. Designed to celebrate the gardens and all the City staff and volunteers who care for them.

The project was funded by Measure DD with additional support from the Friends of the Gardens at Lake Merritt. Implemented in conjunction with the Measure DD: Bellevue Avenue project.

Managed by the Public Art Program, Cultural Affairs Division, Economic & Workforce Development Department.

item.name: Events
item.title: Oakland Online Town Hall
item.body:
Please join Mayor Libby Schaaf on Twitter, Facebook or YouTube for our second online Town Hall this Thursday, March 26, at 6 p.m. She will be joined by Dr. Erica Pan, Interim Health Officer at the Alameda County Public Health Department. Dr. Pan will give an update on the county’s response, the challenges ahead, strategies to stay healthy, and answer your questions about the “do’s and don’ts” of the public health order.

We will also be joined by Alexandria McBride, Oakland’s Chief Resilience Officer to discuss our city’s overall planning and response to the pandemic. We’ll have experts on hand to speak about worker’s benefits, housing concerns, and our assistance to unsheltered residents.

You can start submitting questions here.

Please share this info with a friend and tune in Thursday, 6 p.m. to 8 p.m., on my Twitter, Facebook, or YouTube pages.

item.name: Events
item.title: Special City Council Meeting (open session)
item.body:
To comply with the Alameda County Public Health Officer’s shelter in place order to slow the spread of COVID-19 and maintain social distancing requirements, Oakland City Council’s Special meeting will be held via phone/video conference. Scheduled for Friday, March 27 at 11 am, the Special meeting allows the City Council to advance important legislative work necessary to address the current public health crisis posed by the community spread of novel coronavirus, in compliance with Governor Newsom’s Executive Order N-29-20.

There will be two meetings: a Special Closed Session at 10:00 am and a Special City Council Meeting (open session) at 11:00 am. The public is invited to observe and participate in the meetings as follows:

10:00 am Special Closed Session

TO COMMENT:

To comment on Closed Session items by Zoom video conference line, register before 10:00 AM March 27, 2020 at: https://zoom.us/webinar/register/WNp6b91ySRC2bEEeDcAXr9Q

  • You will receive a confirmation on screen and by email with a link to click before the meeting starts.
  • After you click the link emailed to you, you will be prompted to use the “Raise Your Hand” button to request to speak when Public Comment is being taken on the eligible Agenda item.
  • You will then be unmuted, during your turn, and allowed to make public comments.
  • After the allotted time, you will then be re-muted.
  • All public speakers will be disconnected from the line after all comments are heard and council will proceed with Closed Session.

You will be prompted to “Raise Your Hand” by pressing “*9” to request to speak when Public Comment is being taken on the eligible Agenda Item. You will then be unmuted, during your turn, and allowed to make public comments. After the allotted time, you will then be re-muted

To comment on Closed Session items by phone, dial (for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location): US: +1 669-900-6833 or +1 346-248-7799 or +1 312-626-6799 or +1 929-436-2866 or +1 253-215-8782 or +1 301-715-8592. Then enter Webinar ID: 536 888 246.

You will be prompted to “Raise Your Hand” by pressing “*9” to request to speak when Public Comment is being taken on the eligible Agenda Item. You will then be unmuted, during your turn, and allowed to make public comments. After the allotted time, you will then be re-muted.

11:00 am Special City Council Meeting (open session)

TO OBSERVE the meeting video conference:

  1. View on KTOP Channel 10 Xfinity or ATT Channel 99 Government Access to locate KTOP Channel 10
  2. View from the meeting calendar at: https://oakland.legistar.com/calendar.aspx and click “In Progress”
  3. View on Zoom video conference platform at: https://zoom.us/j/420129689 at the noticed meeting time.

TO LISTEN to the meeting by phone:

  1. Call the numbers below at the noticed meeting time (note: for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location):
  • +1 669-900-6833 or
  • +1 346-248-7799 or
  • +1 929-436-2866 or
  • +1 253-215-8782 or
  • +1 301-715-8592 or
  • +1 312-626-6799
  1. Then enter Webinar ID: 420 129 689. If asked for a participant ID or code, press #.

TO COMMENT:

  1. eComment. Send your comment directly to Council members and staff BEFORE the meeting starts at: https://oakland.legistar.com/calendar.aspx and click on the “eComment” link under “eComment” for the corresponding meeting. eComment submissions close five (5) minutes before posted meeting time.
  2. To comment by Zoom video conference, click the “Raise Your Hand” button to request to speak when Public Comment is being taken on the eligible Agenda item. You will then be unmuted, during your turn, and allowed to make public comments. After the allotted time, you will then be re-muted.
  3. To comment by phone, please call on one of the above-listed phone numbers. You will be prompted to “Raise Your Hand” by pressing “*9” to request to speak when Public Comment is being taken on the eligible Agenda Item. You will then be unmuted, during your turn, and allowed to make public comments. After the allotted time, you will then be re-muted.

ADDITIONAL INSTRUCTIONS:

Instructions on how to join a meeting by video conference are available at: https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362193 - Joining-a-Meeting.

Instructions on how to join a meeting by phone are available at: https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/201362663 Joining-a-meeting-by-phone.

Instructions on how to “Raise Your Hand” are available at: https://support.zoom.us/hc/en-us/articles/205566129 - Raise-Hand-In-Webinar

item.title: Head Start Drive-By Parade
item.body:
Who's that driving through my neighborhood? It's the Head Start Drive-By Parade.

Friday, May 29th from 1 - 4 PM, look out your window and listen for a parade of Head Start cars driving through your neighborhood. As we drive by, make some noise! Cheer us along by clapping, stomping, and shouting as the parade drives by. We are so proud of Head Start families for finishing the school year, and we miss you so much.

Below are links to the parade routes, one loop in West/Central Oakland and another loop in East Oakland.

  • West and Central Oakland Drive-By Route (Mobile-Friendly PDF), or through Google Maps
  • East Oakland Drive-By Route (Mobile-Friendly PDF), or through Google Maps

If you need to step outside to watch, please wear a mask and maintain six feet of social distance. Please note: Children 0 - 2 years old should not wear masks.

For more information, call us at (510) 238 - 3165.

item.name: Events
item.title: A Conversation on Structural Racism and Police Reform in Oakland
item.body:
As we continue to move through this unprecedented and emotionally raw experience in our country, we hope residents can join our virtual Town Hall Tonight at 6 p.m. on our social media channels Facebook , Twitter , Instagram , and YouTube (with closed captioning).

To dial in by phone: (669) 900-6833, 413825986#

This week, we’ll host an honest conversation about the structural racism that exists within our own City systems, our police department, and the real work Oakland is doing to eradicate it.
It is difficult work that is nowhere near done. This moment is ripe for a transformative leap toward justice if together we choose it.

The conversation will be facilitated by Darlene Flynn , City of Oakland Dir. Dept. of Race and Equity. Panelists will include:

  • Civil rights attorney John Burris, who has participated in the department’s reform effort under the negotiated settlement agreement
  • OPD Lt. Fred Shavies, facilitator for the department’s Equity Working Group.
  • Guillermo Cespedes, City of Oakland, Dir. Dept. of Violence Prevention.

We will discuss current events and the long-term efforts to reform OPD and increase Oakland’s non-law enforcement actions to build a safer, healthier, and more beloved city for all.

item.title: KQED On Common Ground: Black Businesses through Pandemic and Protest
item.body:
How are Oakland's Black-owned small businesses navigating these social and economic strains? How are they holding the community together?

I'm excited to join some Community leaders and business owners with KQED's Pendarvis Harshaw for a conversation about the compounding public health crisis, police violence, and how the local governments are addressing these issues.

Special Guest:

  • Eva Paterson, Equal Justice Society
  • Cathy D. Adams, Oakland African American Chamber of Commerce
  • Loren Taylor, Oakland City Council, District 6
  • Tucky Blunt, Blunts and Moore
  • Nenna Joiner, FeelMore Adult Gallery
  • James Queen, New Vision Fitness


Join the conversation Wednesday, June 24th at 6 pm: Register Today

item.name: Events
item.title: Bicyclist & Pedestrian Advisory Commission (BPAC) Virtual Open House / Meet and Greet
item.body:
The City is accepting applications to fill three seats on the Oakland Bicyclist & Pedestrian Advisory Commission (BPAC) for three-year terms starting in January 2021.

The purpose of the BPAC is to advise City Council and City of Oakland staff on bicyclist and pedestrian-specific policies, projects, and programs, and to advocate for safe, effective and equitable bicycle and pedestrian projects and programs throughout Oakland. The minimum qualifications for membership are that an individual must live in Oakland and have a demonstrated history of professional and/or community involvement with bicyclist and/or pedestrian issues. In selecting commissioners, the Mayor will strive for equity and geographic representation of Oakland’s neighborhoods. To apply, please submit an application by 5 pm Wednesday, September 9, 2020 by going to https://www.oaklandca.gov/services/become-a-bpac-commissioner

To learn more, come to our BPAC Virtual Open House / Meet and Greet on August 18th, 2020 from 6-7pm hosted on Zoom by web at https://zoom.us/j/99943548891 or by phone at +1(669) 900-6833 or find your local number at https://zoom.us/u/adHDKKDPa6

item.name: Events
item.title: DOSC Presents: A Good Night's Sleep Symposium 2020

fields.locationDescription: You will receive a confirmation email after registration. You will also receive an email with Zoom Event login in information after October 31, 2020.

item.body:
Join us for a fascinating Zoom Symposium as we learn about sleep and rest, and how they are impacted by our aging, our brain, and by the COVID-19 Pandemic. Researchers, physicians and clinicians from University of San Francisco Memory and Aging Center will be on hand to help us better understand sleep, answer our questions, and to offer some tips and techniques to improve the quality (and quantity) of our rest, relaxation, and sleep.

There will also be drawings for $50 Gift Cards, but you must Register with Event Brite to be entered in the drawing. Winners must be online to claim their prize.

SCHEDULE OF EVENTS

9:30 a.m. Welcome and Introduction

9:35 a.m. – 10:05 a.m. Keynote Address, Dr. Serggio Lanata

10:05 a.m. – 10:35 a.m. “Sleep Hygiene” by Dr. Shelley Zak

10:35 a.m. – 10:50 a.m. Audience Questions for Drs. Lanata and Zak

10:50 a.m. – 10:55 a.m. Relaxation Tips

10:55 a.m. – 11:00 a.m. Break

11:00 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. “Sleeping Your Way to a Healthier You,” Christine Walsh, Ph.D.

11:30 a.m. – 12:00 Noon “ Sleep Apnea, Insomnia and Other Sleep Thieves,” Yishan Xu, Ph.D.

12:00 p.m. – 12:15 p.m. Audience Questions for Drs. Walsh and Xu

12:15 p.m. – 12:30 p.m. Prize Drawings

item.title: Stress Busters: Silencing your Thoughts Workshop

fields.locationDescription:
To join as an audio phone call:

1. Call: 1-669-900-9128

2. After the first prompt, press (meeting ID): 881-8961-4817 #

3. After next prompt, press #

4. After 3rd prompt, press (password) 848262

item.body:
Stress comes in many ways. It’s that uneasy feeling we get when we're upset -- whether it's because we're angry, worried, depressed or upset for other reasons. In these challenging times, it's very easy to be stressed and anxious.

In our Stress Buster workshops, we’ll learn how stress starts and a simple effective method to handle your reaction to situations. You’ll learn a five step process to reduce stress and help you better respond to any situation in a helpful less stressful way. Stress Busters (also known as Ding Sum) has been serving seniors in the San Francisco Bay Area for over 30 years, reaching 900 people through monthly in person seminars, and now via Zoom!

This weekly series is fun and practical. Leave each session with new practical insights on how to better handle whatever life throws at you.

Time: 10:00am - 10:30am

Duration: 10 weeks then in March it moves to monthly (4th Wednesdays of the month).

Presenter: Stress Busters of San Francisco also known as “Ding Sum"

item.name: Events
item.title: Black History Month
item.body: Black History Month is an annual celebration of achievements by African Americans and a time for recognizing their central role in U.S. history. Also known as African American History Month, the event grew out of “Negro History Week,” the brainchild of noted historian Carter G. Woodson and other prominent African Americans. Since 1976, every U.S. president has officially designated the month of February as Black History Month.

item.name: Events
item.title: Budget Town Hall with Councilmember Kalb
item.body:
On May 7th, Mayor Libby Schaaf released her 2021 - 2023 Budget.

As a part of the Council President’s Budget Team, Councilmember Kalb is looking forward to working with Council President Fortunato Bas and all his colleagues and city staff on the upcoming Fiscal Years 2021-23 Budget. As always, the aim is to maintain and enhance necessary and vital services despite limits on our financial resources.

Our District 1 team has been receiving various budget-related inquiries. To provide most current information and hear our constituents' thoughts, suggestions, and ideas for the upcoming two-year budget, Councilmember Kalb is hosting a Budget Town Hall with City Finance staff and Mayor Libby Schaaf on Thursday, May 20th at 6:00pm.

Please RSVP here. The Zoom link for this event will be sent in a separate email. The Town Hall will also be streamed live on Councilmember Kalb’s City Council Facebook page.

Please feel free to provide your feedback on the Councilmember Kalb's Budget Priorities.

Watch the video of this event on Facebook Live.

item.body:
Please join staff at the City of Oakland for a public zoom question & answer session on July 15th, 2021 from 2-3pm. Staff will share information about the recent release of its Homekey Request for Qualifications (RFQ), with time for questions at the end.

More on the City of Oakland’s Homekey RFQ:

The City of Oakland Department of Housing and Community Development has released its Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for qualified housing sponsors to own, operate, and provide services for permanent affordable housing for homeless and formerly homeless individuals and households under the State Homekey program. The RFQ seeks to identify a qualified pool of Homekey sponsors in anticipation of the 2021 State Homekey NOFA this summer.

All qualifications must be submitted via the Project Sponsor Application form on the City of Oakland Homekey page: https://www.oaklandca.gov/topics/city-homekey-rfq.

The City’s Homekey page also includes a Seller Expression of Interest Form for sellers interested in selling or leasing their property for Homekey projects, as well as a Sponsor Partnership Expression of Interest Form for sponsors interested in partnering with other sponsors.
item.eventContact: Please send questions to HCDinfo@oaklandca.gov.

item.title: National Night Out

fields.locationName: Oakland - numerous citywide locations -- see list after July 23. 2021

item.body:
National Night Out is America's block party night. An opportunity for neighbors to get to know each other. This years theme is disaster and emergency preparedness. Neighbors are encouraged to organize a block party or other outdoor event on the sidewalk or in the street. During the event, meet and greet, share contact information and develop plans to help one another in an emergency.

If registered with the City of Oakland, neighborhood groups can close their block off for free on NNO only. Registered parties will receive a special host packet.

Wear a mask and physically distance.

When Neighbors Know Each Other, Neighborhoods are Safer!

item.body:
你是屋崙 (奧克蘭) 市的小型物業業主或租戶嗎？請參加我們的講座；你將可了解屋崙 (奧克蘭) 市《租金與迫遷正當理由條例》(Rent and Just Cause for Eviction Ordinances) 規定的權利和責任。講習主題包括租金水平和租金管制、押金、和迫遷

請注意：登記網站和講習網站會用英文來問您的名字(FIRST NAME)，姓名(LAST NAME)，和電子郵件(EMAIL)。我們很抱歉本網站沒有中文版。如果您需要幫助來登記，請致電(510)238-3721。我們的辦公室可以幫您註冊。

Are you a tenant or landlord in Oakland? Please join us for an overview of your rights and responsibilities under Oakland’s Rent and Just Cause for Eviction Ordinances. Topics include rent levels and rent control, security deposits, and evictions.

Please be aware that that the registration and webinar websites will ask for your first name, last name, & email in English. There is no Chinese support for these websites, for which we apologize. If you need help registering, please call our office at (510) 238-3721.

item.title: First Oakland Poet Inaugural Address - Dr. Ayodele Nzinga
item.body:
The City of Oakland's First Oakland Poet Laureate Inaugural Address with opening remarks from Mayor Libby Schaaf, Cultural Affairs Division Manager Roberto Bedoya and performances by prominent Bay Area artists and poets. We'll have a chance to hear Dr. Ayodele Nzinga's inaugural speech and a special reading.

  • Additional readings by Marvin X (Guest griot), David Flores (current Poet Laureate of Richmond), Eevelyn Mitchell (current Poet Laureate of El Cerrito), and Tongo Eisen-Martin (current Poet Laureate of SF).
  • Music by Mia Pixley
  • Theatre by Century Cycle
  • Rainin Fellow and Director of the Lorraine Hansberry Theatre, Margo Hall (reading from Gem of the Ocean), and Lower Bottom Playa, Reginald Wilkins (reading from Two Trains Running)

item.name: Events
item.title: DVP Town Hall: Determined To Thrive
item.body:
The Department of Violence Prevention is hosting a community town hall on creating a safer, healthier Oakland. This convening will support the Department of Violence Prevention, partner agencies, and community stakeholders engage in the conversations and co-learning necessary to deepen our collective knowledge, strengthen our partnerships, and fortify our commitment to community healing, safety, and justice.

The goals of the Town Hall are to:

  • Outline the DVP’s priorities and values around community safety
  • Raise awareness about best practices in violence prevention and community safety
  • Build shared understanding about the critical work community-based organizations are engaging
  • Strengthen partnerships and inspire creative cross-sector collaboration
  • Fortify commitment to centering the strengths and needs of our most marginalized in our city-wide public safety, healing, and justice strategies

Speakers and Panelists include:

  • Guillermo Cespedes, DVP Chief
  • Sarai Crain, DVP Deputy Chief
  • Kentrell Killens, DVP Direct Service Coordinator
  • Mike Muscadine, Communities United for Restorative Youth Justice
  • Briana Manning, Urban Peace Movement
  • Carlos Jackson, Youth Alive
  • Chantal Hildebrand, Alliance for Girls

Register today and spread the word!

*The meeting will be recorded to support broader community access.

Come learn more about evictions, the local moratorium, and how it impacts tenancies in Oakland.

On Monday, November 22, The Department of Violence Prevention, in partnership with Urban Peace Movement (UPM), Hoover-Foster RAC, Khadafy Washington Foundation, TRYBE, Inc., Communities United for Restorative Youth Justice (CURYJ), Root Community Health Center (ROOTS), Building Opportunities for Self-Sufficiency (BOSS), Adamika Village, Basic Ministry and Homies Empowerment is kicking off the 2021 Town Nights events at eight locations across the city of Oakland! item.name: Events
item.title: Cultural Hub #1: Oakland Asian Cultural Center (OACC) Asian Pacific New Year Celebration
item.body:
In recognition of the diversity of new year’s festivities across the Asian Pacific region, OACC presents a hybrid celebration of Asian Pacific New Year traditions featuring in-person and virtual content for audiences of all ages during February and April 2022. This celebration will also include gathering visions and solutions for the future of Oakland as part of the Oakland General Plan Update process. See the OACC website for more information: https://oacc.cc/event/oacc-apny-2022/.

OACC will celebrate Lunar New Year, the Year of the Tiger, with 3 days of virtual content (Feb 5th, 11th, and 12th) and an in-person festival on February 6th highlighting Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese and other cultural traditions and artforms connected to the Lunar New Year holiday. Enjoy virtual and in-person vendor and community booth marketplaces, cultural demos, storytelling, and artistic performances.

Saturday, February 5 - Lunar New Year Virtual Kick-off

Time: Event begins streaming at 12noon on OACC's Youtube

Sunday, February 6 - In-Person Festival

Time: 11am-3pm

Location: Pacific Renaissance Plaza, 388 Ninth Street

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Update: Housing Element Workshop 1 - Housing Sites
item.body:
Help plan for housing in Oakland! Join us at the first of four upcoming workshops on Oakland’s Housing Element – our plan for next eight years on where new housing should be located, and what we can do meet the housing needs of the community. Your input will help the team determine how the City plans for housing to meet the needs of our diverse and growing city!

Learn more about:

  • The Housing Element;
  • Oakland's housing needs, including how much housing Oakland must plan for; and
  • Areas that have been zoned for more housing.

Give us your thoughts on:

  • Your vision for housing in Oakland;
  • Additional places where you would like to see new housing located; and
  • The types of housing the City should plan for at each site.

Date: February 10, 6pm-8pm

Register: https://dyettandbhatia.zoom.us...

item.name: Events
item.title: Head Start Advisory Board Meeting

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Update: Housing Element Workshop 2 - Housing Programs and Inclusive Neighborhoods
item.body:
Help plan for housing in Oakland! Join us at the second of four upcoming workshops on Oakland’s Housing Element – our plan for next eight years on where new housing should be located, and what we can do meet the housing needs of the community. Your input will help the team determine how the City plans for housing to meet the needs of our diverse and growing city!

Learn more about:

  • Current City programs to promote housing, including affordable housing;
  • State laws and City policies that allow for more housing in single-family zones; and
  • Initial discussion on anti-displacement and housing protections (please note: this topic will be covered in depth at Workshop 3, date forthcoming).

Give us your thoughts on:

  • Your vision for housing in Oakland;
  • Programs that will increase the supply and diversity of housing;
  • Zoning rules that should be changed – e.g., parking, building heights, density; and
  • Ways to provide more housing opportunities in existing neighborhoods.

See agenda below.

  • Recap Workshop #1
  • Oakland’s current housing needs
    • Current City programs to promote housing, including affordable housing
    • State laws and City policies
  • Initial information on anti-displacement and housing protections (more covered in workshop #3)
  • Small group discussion
    • Programs that will increase the supply and diversity of housing
    • Zoning rules that should be changed
    • Ways to provide more housing opportunities in existing neighborhoods
    • Initial ideas about anti-displacement and tenant protections

Date: February 17, 6pm-8pm

Register: https://dyettandbhatia.zoom.us...

item.title: General Plan Pop-Up #9: Community Healing Event with Asian Health Services!
item.body:
Asian Health Services will be hosting a Community Healing Event to support Chinatown and victims of hate, and celebrate Black History Month and the beginning of the Year of the Tiger! There will be free food, live cultural performances, on-site COVID-19 vaccines, and testing. Everyone is invited. There will also be resource booths, including the Black Arts Movement Business District Community Development Corporation, Oakland (BAMBD CDC). Visit BAMBD CDC's booth to play an interactive activity about housing, enter a raffle, and learn about the Oakland General Plan process. Share your experiences on housing and environmental justice with their staff!

Location: Madison Park, 810 Jackson Street, Oakland, CA 94607

Time: 3pm-6pm

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Pop Up #10: Black Joy Parade
item.body:
On Sunday, February 27, the fifth annual Black Joy Parade will celebrate the Black experience in downtown Oakland including Black-owned businesses, local artists, and others. The outdoor street festival is free and family-friendly. Come visit the Malonga Arts Residents Association (MARA) of the Malonga Casquelord Center for the Arts at their booth along the parade route. Learn more about MARA's talented artist and residential community. Staff will also be engaging residents on the Oakland General Plan by conducting brief informational interviews on experiences of housing and environmental justice. Learn more about the parade at: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/t....

The parade begins on 14th and Broadway in downtown Oakland, Ca at 12:30pm PST. Following the parade, The Black Joy Parade celebration will be held on 19th and Broadway and feature a curation of 200+ local artists, craftsmen, food vendors, performances and more.

item.name: Events
item.title: Black History Month Celebration at Hoover Elementary
item.body:
Join us in the Hoover Elementary School Garden for a Black History Month garden workday and celebration, hosted by the Black Liberation Walking Tour! Come chat with city staff at our booth to learn more about the Oakland General Plan Update. We'll be handing out candy and informational postcards as well as conducting brief interviews with community members on their experiences of housing and environmental justice in Oakland.

Location: Hoover Elementary School, 890 Brockhurst St., Enter on 33rd & West

Time: 11AM - 2 PM

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Pop-Up at Akoma Market
item.body:
Shop locally, skate with your friends and family, build community, and share your vision and solutions for the future of Oakland as part of the General Plan Update process. The market and Oakland visioning is a great capstone to your weekend.

Location: Liberation Park, 7101 Foothill Blvd (MacArthur and 73rd Avenue), Oakland, CA 94605

Time: 10am-3pm

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Update - Housing Element Workshop 3
item.body:
Housing Workshop #3: You're invited to the third of four workshops on Oakland's Housing Element, the blueprint for housing the City’s residents, at all economic levels including low income and households with special needs. This workshop will include:

  • A quick overview of the Housing Element and components
  • A presentation on housing need and affirmatively furthering fair housing in Oakland
  • Community discussion on strategies to address housing protections and preservation, including tenant protections, preserving existing affordable housing, creating more homeownership, and community planning.

Your input at this workshop will help guide development of strategies, programs, and actions in Oakland's Housing Element!

Location: Virtual, Register here: https://dyettandbhatia.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZYrc-GurToiH90hPHLE3-U-bRgXACPxi4wX

Time: 10am-12pm

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Townhall 1
item.body:
Join the General Plan Team at the first of two town hall meetings where we will present an overview of the General Plan Update and background information on planning topics, such as land use, environmental justice, safety, parks and open space, transportation, and more. The town hall meetings will include a presentation as well as fun, interactive activities to gather community's input on issues and priorities in the City. What issues do you care about the most? Learn more and let us know!

Location: Virtual Zoom Meeting (registration link coming soon)

Time: 10am-12pm

item.name: Events
item.title: General Plan Update: Housing Element Workshop 4
item.body:
Housing Workshop #4: You're invited to the fourth of four workshops on Oakland's Housing Element, the blueprint for housing the City’s residents, at all economic levels including low income and households with special needs. This workshop will include:

  • A quick overview of the Housing Element and components
  • A presentation on strategies, policies, and programs to be included in the Housing Element, developed using input from Workshops 1, 2, and 3.
  • Opportunities for community discussion and feedback on strategies, policies, and programs.

Your input at this workshop will help finalize strategies, programs, and actions in Oakland's Housing Element! c
